page.title: 14OVER WYRESDALE:TRANSPORT
page.content: Very few people are without transport today, the most popular form being the petrol-engined motor car. This makes public transport almost unnecessary except for the conveyance of school children and people under the age of 17. The public bus service only runs 3 days per week when secondary schools are on holiday. On Sundays there is no service at all. During school holidays on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays a morning service runs to Lancaster but there is no return service, no-one knows why. Children under 11 years of age in the area, attending school and having 2 miles or more to travel are entitled to free transport by minibus. This also runs a feeder service to convey children over 11 years to the public bus to Lancaster. All goods are carried by diesel-engined lorries or vans. There is no railway or canal.
